perturbation.original_text:
You must sign a general release if you renew or transfer your franchise. California Corporation Code 31512 voids a waiver of your
rights under the Franchise Investment Law (California Corporations Code 31000 through 31516). Business and Professions Code
20010 voids a waiver of your rights under the Franchise Relations Act (Business and Professions Code 20000 through 20043).
perturbation.changed_text: You must sign a general release if you renew or transfer your franchise. By signing this agreement, you fully waive all rights and claims, known or unknown, under the Franchise Investment Law (California Corporations Code 31000 through 31516) and the Franchise Relations Act (Business and Professions Code 20000 through 20043). This waiver is unconditional and irrevocable.
perturbation.explanation: This change directly contradicts California Corporation Code 31512 and Business and Professions Code 20010, which explicitly void waivers of rights under the Franchise Investment Law and the Franchise Relations Act, respectively. The modified text attempts to enforce such a waiver, creating a legal contradiction.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Corporation Code 31512; Business and Professions Code 20010

perturbation.original_text:
The Master Franchise Agreement requires non-binding mediation. The mediation will occur in New York with the costs being borne
by equally by the parties. Prospective franchisees are encouraged to consult private legal counsel to determine the applicability of
California and federal laws (such as Business and Professions Code Section 20040.5 and Code of Civil Procedure Section 1281) to any
provisions of a franchise agreement restricting venue to a forum outside the State of California.
perturbation.changed_text: The Master Franchise Agreement requires mandatory binding arbitration in New York. The franchisee is responsible for all costs associated with arbitration, including travel and legal fees. The decision of the arbitrator shall be final and non-appealable.
perturbation.explanation: This change attempts to force franchisees into binding arbitration in New York, and makes them responsible for all costs, conflicting with California's interest in protecting franchisees from unfair dispute resolution processes. California law may limit the enforceability of mandatory arbitration clauses, particularly those that are one-sided or require out-of-state venues.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Code of Civil Procedure Section 1281; potentially California Franchise Relations Act (Business and Professions Code 20000 through 20043) depending on the specific facts and circumstances.

perturbation.original_text:
The Master Franchise Agreement contains covenants not to compete which extend beyond the termination of the agreement. These
provisions may not be enforceable under California law.
perturbation.changed_text: The Master Franchise Agreement contains covenants not to compete which extend for a period of 10 years beyond the termination of the agreement, within a 500-mile radius, and applies to any business involved in the preparation or sale of soup or related food products. This covenant is fully enforceable.
perturbation.explanation: This change specifies a very broad and lengthy non-compete agreement (10 years, 500-mile radius) that is likely unenforceable under California law, which generally disfavors such covenants, especially those that are broad in scope or duration. Business and Professions Code Section 16600 generally invalidates non-compete agreements.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Business and Professions Code Section 16600
